title.value: Escaping the Sample Trap: Fast and Accurate Epistemic Uncertainty Estimation with Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs)
title.justification: The title clearly indicates the primary focus of the research, which is a novel approach for epistemic uncertainty estimation using PaiDEs.
title.quote: Escaping the Sample Trap: Fast and Accurate Epistemic Uncertainty Estimation with Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs)

extractions.description: This paper introduces Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs), a novel approach for epistemic uncertainty estimation in ensembles of deep learning models. The method estimates uncertainty using the pairwise distance between model components to establish entropy bounds without relying on sample-based Monte Carlo estimators. It demonstrates higher efficiency and accuracy, especially in high-dimensional settings. The paper validates the approach through a series of experiments on synthetic data and multi-dimensional robotic environments.

type.justification: The paper includes a series of experiments and evaluations to validate the proposed approach.
type.quote: To validate our approach, we conducted a series of experiments commonly used to evaluate epistemic uncertainty estimation.

name.justification: The core contribution of the paper is a new method for estimating epistemic uncertainty in model predictions.
name.quote: We establish the framework for the application of PaiDEs in the context of estimating epistemic uncertainty for deep ensembles with probabilistic outputs.

name.justification: The paper demonstrates the advantages of PaiDEs within an active learning framework.
name.quote: For each experimental setting, an Active Learning framework was applied to demonstrate the advantages of PaiDEs for epistemic uncertainty estimation.

name.justification: Normalizing Flows are used in the ensembles to model epistemic uncertainty effectively.
name.quote: In this study, we showcase the application of PaiDEs for epistemic uncertainty estimation for ensembles with probabilistic outputs, specifically Normalizing Flows (NFs).

name.justification: PaiDEs (Pairwise-Distance Estimators) are explicitly introduced and evaluated for epistemic uncertainty estimation in the paper.
name.quote: This work introduces a novel approach for epistemic uncertainty estimation for ensemble models using pairwise-distance estimators (PaiDEs).

is_contributed.justification: PaiDEs are the main contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: This work introduces a novel approach for epistemic uncertainty estimation for ensemble models using pairwise-distance estimators (PaiDEs).

is_executed.justification: The experiments executing PaiDEs involved high-dimensional settings and deep learning models, often requiring GPU resources.
is_executed.quote: Training was conducted using 16GB RAM on Intel Gold 6148 Skylake @ 2.4 GHz CPUs and NVidia V100SXM2 (16G memory) GPUs.

is_compared.justification: PaiDEs are compared to Monte Carlo estimators in various experiments.
is_compared.quote: PaiDEs offer a non-sample based alternative for estimating information-based criterion in ensemble models with probabilistic outputs.

referenced_paper_title.value: Estimating Mixture Entropy with Pairwise Distances
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced methodology and theoretical foundation for PaiDEs come from this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Their derivation and properties follow from Kolchinsky & Tracey (2017)

name.justification: Normalizing Flow Ensembles, specifically Nflows Base, were used to effectively model both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty.
name.quote: We utilized an ensemble technique named Nflows Base, which has previously shown robust performance in estimating both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty on robotic datasets by leveraging normalizing flows.

is_contributed.justification: Nflows Base is based on prior research and is not introduced as a new model in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Our contributions build upon the previously established Nflows Base.

is_executed.justification: The paper includes the execution of Nflows Base in its experimental setup.
is_executed.quote: In this study, we utilized an ensemble technique named Nflows Base, which has previously shown robust performance in estimating both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty on robotic datasets.

is_compared.justification: Nflows Base performances are analyzed and compared as part of the experimental results.
is_compared.quote: Berry & Meger (2023) showed that Nflows Base outperforms previous methods when estimating epistemic uncertainty.

referenced_paper_title.value: Normalizing Flow Ensembles for Rich Aleatoric and Epistemic Uncertainty Modeling
referenced_paper_title.justification: Nflows Base and its application for uncertainty estimation are based on this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Berry & Meger (2023) showed that Nflows Base outperforms previous methods when estimating epistemic uncertainty.

name.justification: Pendulum-v0 is used in the experimental evaluations for epistemic uncertainty.
name.quote: We evaluated PaiDEs on two 1D benchmarks, hetero and bimodal. The ground-truth data for hetero and bimodal can be seen in Figure 2 on the left graphs with the blue dots with the orange bar chart corresponding to the density. [...] In addition to the 1D environments, we tested our methods over four multi-dimensional environments (Pendulum-v0, Hopper-v2, Ant-v2, and Humanoid-v2) (Todorov et al., 2012).

referenced_paper_title.value: MuJoCo: A physics engine for model-based control
referenced_paper_title.justification: MuJoCo is referenced as the environment framework for Pendulum-v0, Hopper-v2, Ant-v2, Humanoid-v2.

name.justification: The experiments make use of environments from the OpenAI Gym library.
name.quote: Note that for Ant-v2 and Humanoid-v2, the dimensions representing their contact forces were eliminated as Mujoco-v2 had a bug, always returning zero for those dimensions.1 Regarding the multi-dimensional environments, namely Pendulum-v0, Hopper-v2, Ant-v2, and Humanoid-v2, the training sets and test sets were collected using different approaches. The training sets were obtained by applying a random policy, while the test sets were generated using an expert policy. This methodology was employed to ensure diversity between the training and test datasets. Notably, the OpenAI Gym library was utilized, with minor modifications (Brockman et al., 2016).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper explicitly mentions the use of the OpenAI Gym library for the experimental environments.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Notably, the OpenAI Gym library was utilized, with minor modifications
